question: A patient with sulphur granules discharging from sinus, suggestive of infection with -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i.e., Mycetoma o Mycetoma are chronic, slowly progressive infections of the subcutaneous tissue usually of the foot caused by a number of Actinomycetes and filamentous fungi.o The disease usually begins as a small subcutaneous swelling of the foot, which enlarges, burrowing into deeper tissues and tracking to the surface as multiple sinuses discharging viscid, seropurulent fluid containing granules.

question: Sulphur granules in actinomycosis consists of -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i.e., Organisms o The diagnosis is most commonly made by microscopic identification of sulphur granules (an in-vivo matrix of bacteria calcium phosphate, and host material). - Harrison 18/e 1329o The sulfur granules are bacterial colonies and will be found to consist of a dense network of thin Gram positive filaments, surrounded by a peripheral zone of swollen radiating club shaped structures, presenting a sun ray appearance. The 'clubs' are believed to be antigen - antibody complexes.
